Problem:
Consider a complex function given by \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a constant frequency and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. This function is analyzed under the transformation defined by \\( g(z) = e^{i\theta}z \\), with \\( \theta \\) being a constant phase shift.

If \\( g(z) \\) is applied to \\( z_0 = 1 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve according to \\( z(t) \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(T) \\) at T be the same as if \\( z_0 = 1 \\) was directly evolved to T under \\( z(t) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(z) \\) modifies the initial condition by adding a phase shift \\( \theta \\). The evolution of this new initial condition under \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) results in a trajectory that is phase-shifted by \\( \theta \\) compared to the unmodified trajectory, leading to \\( z(T) = e^{i\omega T + i\theta} \\), not \\( e^{i\omega T} \\).
